 - iii - SUMMARY While the literature on social accounting matrices, (SAMs) has been growing apace, details of the issues which arise in constructing a SAM are not always documented. It is therefore thought worthwhile, to make generally available the SAM for Malaysia which is described in this study, since it addresses a number of conceptual issues and their practical solution which have not been treated elsewhere as far as we know. In this sense the present study is a sequel to earlier work on Sri Lanka, (Pyatt, Roe, et. al. (1977)) but with greater emphasis on the statistical problems of constructing a SAM and less on the application of results. It assumes some familiarity with the subject, such as might be obtained from King (1981), Bank Staff Working Paper #463. The SAM described in this paper is a large one, with a level of detail more nearly that at which national accounts are typically compiled, rather than the more aggregated formats which are often adopted as a basis for macro models or analysis. Indeed, one reason for undertaking this study was to explore the implications of working at different levels, starting with a higher level of disaggregation than that ultimately sustained. Malaysia was chosen for this study because of the strength of the pri- mary materials available. These include an excellent set of national accounts based on the commodity balance approach. These made possible an initial ex- ploration of the strengths and weaknesses of using market prices as the basis for evaluation of commodity balances, leading to some formal, algebraic treatment of the reasons for preferring this approach to other conventions.
 - iv - An extensive household survey, covering incomes, expenditures and employ- ment issues complements the national accounts in defining the principle data sources. It makes possible the treatment of household income and outlay out- counts in some detail, and raises a number of issues which the text attempts to address, concerning the reconciliation of national accounts and household survey data, not least with regard to savings. Unfortunately, the scope of these primary data sources is largely restricted to the Peninsular or West Malaysian states, while the whole of Malaysia, including the East Malaysian states of Sabah and Sarawak, is the subject of this study. Efforts to meet this wider definition introduce some further novelty. In the first place, it has been necessary to define a two- region SAM at the conceptual level. It turns out that, while there is nothing special about having two regions rather than several - the issues hinge on having any number greater than one - there are some important questions to be resolved at this stage. Next, given the conceptual framework, the approach is essentially to estimate a SAM for East Malaysia and then to form the SAM for all Malaysia by combining this with a matched matrix for the West Malaysia states. Given the sparcity of data, estimating the SAM for East Malaysia calls for an imaginative approach along lines similar to those which have previously been adopted in the regional input-output literature. These are the major novelties to be discussed in this paper, and they should be of interest to others concerned with SAM estimation methods, They lead initially to a very large matrix, which is then reduced in size to yield a final version in which details are determined on the basis of interest and accuracy.
 - v - RESUME S'il existe aujourd'hui d'assez nombreux ouvrages sur les matrices de comptabilite sociale (MCS), peu d'entre eux traitent dans le detail les questions qui se posent lors de leur construction. Il serait donc utile, a notre avis, de diffuser largement la MCS pour la Malaisie decrite dans cette etude qui, nous semble-t-il, analyse pour la premiere fois un cer- tain nombre de problemes theoriques et propose des solutions pratiques. En ce sens, le pr6sent document est la suite du travail deja effectue sur Sri Lanka, (MM. Pyatt, Roe, et divers collaborateurs (1977)) mais fait une plus grande place aux problemes statistiques pos6s par la construction d'une MCS qu'a l'application des resultats. Sa comprehension suppose une certaine connaissance du sujet, que l'on peut acquerir en se r6ferant au document de travail de la Banque No 463 de M. King (1981). La MCS decrite dans ce document comporte un tres grand nombre de lignes et de colonnes et contient des details que l'on trouve generalement dans les comptes nationaux plutot que dans les bases de donnees plus con- cises, utilis6es le plus souvent pour les modeles ou analyses macroecono- miques. En fait, l'un des buts meme de l1'tude etait de comparer les merites de plusieurs methodes de travail, en commencant par un niveau de d6sagregation plus pousse que celui retenu en fin de compte. On a choisi la Malaisie pour mener cette etude a cause de l'impor- tance des donnees primaires disponibles qui comprennent notamment un ensemble de comptes nationaux tres fiables etablis a partir de la methode
 - vi - de l"'equilibre emplois-ressources". Ces donnees ont permis un premier examen des avantages et des inconv6nients de l'emploi des prix du marche comme base d'evaluation de l'equilibre emplois-ressources et d'exposer, sous forme theorique et alg6brique les raisons de preferer cette methode a d'autres conventions. Une grande enquete sur les menages, portant sur les revenus, les d6penses et l'emploi, constitue, avec les comptes nationaux, la principale source de donn6es. Elle fournit des renseignements detaill6s sur les revenus et les d6penses des menages et souleve un certain nombre de ques- tions, auxquelles les auteurs de ce document s'efforcent d'apporter une r6ponse, au sujet de l'harmonisation des comptes nationaux et des chiffres tires de l'enquete sur les menages, en particulier en ce qui concerne l'epargne. Malheureusement, ces donnees primairea, n'existent pour la plupart que pour la Malaisie peninsulaire ou Malaisie occidentale alors que c'est l'ensemble du pays y compris les etats de la Malaisie orientale, (Sabah et Sarawak) qui fait l'objet de l'4tude. I1 a donc fallu innover. En pre- mier lieu, on a ete amene a definir ce que devait etre, sur le plan theo- rique, une MCS pour deux regions. En r6alit6, l'inclusion de plus de deux regions n'ajouterait rien au probl&me, qui reside dans le fait d'en etu- dier plus d'une, et certaines questions importantes doivent etre r6solues A ce stade. Une fois le cadre th6orique choisi, la methode consiste essentiellement A proceder A des estimations afin d'etablir une MCS pour la Malaisie orientale puis a construire une MCS pour l'ensemble du pays en
 - vii - combinant la premiere matrice avec une matrice concordante pour les Etats de Malaisie occidentale. Compte tenu du manque de donnees, il faut, pour proc6der aux estimations concernant la Malaisie orientale, adopter la meme approche imaginative que pour l1etablissement de tableaux regionaux des entrees-sorties. Telles sont les principales innovations dont il est question dans ce document; elles devraient interesser les personnes travaillant sur des methodes d'estimation en vue de l'etablissement de MCS. Elles menent au depart a la construction d'une matrice tres detaillee qui est ensuite reduite et dont la dimension definitive est determinee par le degr6 de desagregation qu'on souhaite et peut atteindre.
 - viji. - Extracto Si bien la bibliografia sobre las matrices de contabilidad social (MCS) ha aumentado de prisa, no siempre se documentan los detalles de los problemas que se plantean cuando se construye una MCS. Por lo tanto, se considera conveniente divulgar la preparada para Malasia que se describe en este estudio, puesto que encara una serie de cuestiones de concepto, asi como su soluci6n practica, que de acuerdo con nuestra informaci6n no han sido tratadas hasta la fecha. En este sentido, este estudio es un corolario de otro anterior sobre Sri Lanka (Pyatt, Roe y col.(1977)), pero con mas hincapie en los problemas estadisticos que intervienen en la preparaci6n de una MCS y menos en la aplicaci6n de los resultados. Supone cierto conocimiento del tema, por ejemplo, la lectura del documento de trabajo del personal del Banco Mundial No.463, preparado por King (1981). La MCS que se describe en este informe es grande, con un nivel de detalle mas semejante al que se utiliza tipicamente para compilar las cuentas nacionales que a los formatos mas globales que se adoptan con frecuencia como base para los modelos o analisis macroecon6micos. De hecho, una de las razones para abordar este estudio fue poder explorar los efectos que tiene trabajar en distintos niveles, comenzando con un nivel mayor de desglose del que se utiliza por uiltimo. Se eligi6 Malasia para este estudio debido a la solidez de los elementos primarios disponibles, entre ellos, excelentes cuentas nacionales basadas en el enfoque de la balanza de bienes. Permitieron una primera exploraci6n de los
 - ix - puntos fuertes y debiles de la utilizaci6n de los precios de mercado como base para la evaluaci6n de las balanzas de bienes, lo que llev6 a un tratamiento algebraico formal de las razones para preferir este enfoque a otros convencionales. Una encuesta amplia de las unidades familiares, que abarca ingresos, gastos y empleo, se utiliza como complemento de las cuentas nacionales para definir las fuentes primarias de datos. Permite tratar el ingreso de la unidad familiar y las cuentas de gastos con cierto detalle, y plantea una serie de problemas relativos a la reconciliaci6n de los datos de las cuentas nacionales y de la encuesta familiar, y tambien con respecto a los ahorros, que este estudio trata de abordar. Lamentablemente, el alcance de estas fuentes primarias de datos se limita en gran medida a los estados de la peninsula o de Malasia Occidental, en tanto que este estudio abarca la totalidad del pais, incluidos los estados de Sabah y Sarawak. Al tratar de aplicar esta definici6n mas amplia, se introducen algunos otros aspectos nuevos. En primer lugar, ha sido necesario definir en el nivel conceptual una MCS de dos regiones. Ocurre que, si bien no hay nada especial en tener dos regiones en lugar de varias --todo depende de tener un numero cualquiera mayor que uno-- hay ciertas cuestiones importantes que deben resolverse en esta etapa. Luego, dado el marco conceptual, el metodo es esencialmente estimar una MCS para Malasia Oriental y luego formar la que corresponde a todo el pais, combinando la primera con una matriz adecuada a los estados de Malasia Occidental. Dado que se dispone de pocos datos, la estimaci6n de la MCS de Malasia Oriental requiere un metodo imaginativo que siga lineamientos similares a los que se han adoptado anteriormente en la bibliografia sobre el insumo-producto de la regi6n.
 Estas son las novedades principales que se examinan en este informe y sin duda seran de interes para los que se dedican a los m6todos de estimaci6n de MCS. Inicialmente, llevan a una matriz nwuy grande, que luego se reduce en tamaiio para tener una versi6n final en la que se determinan los detalles de acuerdo al interes y a la precision.

 - xvii - Preface This study was completed in 1978, and for that reason, and because its subject matter is the Malaysian economy in 1970, the material presented is now somewhat dated. This notwithstanding, we have received a steady stream of requests for documentation of this social accounting study of Malaysia. This may be because it remains the latest (and perhaps the last), in a series of exercises which have taken us personally from Iran to Sri Lanka; to Swaziland; and hence to Malaysia, with the results reported here. Increasingly, others have been undertaking similar exercises in a wide variety of countries, motivated perhaps by the relevance of social accounting matrices (SAMs) not only for the collation and synthesis of data but also as a basis for macroeconomic analysis, planning and modeling. In pioneering new developments, it is always useful to be able to refer to the experience of others. Accordingly, one reason for presenting this study now is as a point of reference for others to follow. A second set of reasons refer to the motivation of the work undertaken. Complementary to the desire to construct a data basis for modeling, our purpose has been to evolve methods by which national income accounts can be transformed from a documentation of production statistics to a potent statement of what an economy is like. We do not claim to have succeeded entirely, and this characterization of both national accounts and our aspirations for them is admittedly overdrawn. But it would be dishonest to withhold that we approach our subject with a certain emotion; and with a concomitant concern for data as a step towards some other sort of under- standing.
 - xviii - This is not, then, simply a text on some statistical methods of national accounting applied to Malaysia. If it were, then we would be more concerned about the limitations of our work as set out here, since it has several features which time, patience and more of the statistician's skill could undoubtedly refashion for the better. As it is, we have undertaken our study with the fullest cooperation and support, especially from Malaysia, and regard the results as a serious factual statement of Malaysia in 1970. In our view it provides a legitimate basis for further analysis and commentary within the limitations which the text endeavors to describe. There remains much more to illustrate than we have been able to exemplify here. But we do feel that we now have a basis from which to recommend that accounts for other national economies can and should be developed along the lines we have tried to illustrate here. The motivation for our work has been to develop conventional schemas of national accounting so that they cease to revolve around production structure and commodity balances. Instead, we see the living standards of different socioeconomic groups within society as the focal point of national accounting. Production structure and commodity balances are important determinants of the setting within which these living standards are determined. But they are complementary to the detailed income and outlay accounts of households of different types, and by no means a substitute for direct information on who receives what as a result of economic activity. We make no claim of novelty for this perspective on what national accounting ought to be about. But contemporary demonstration of the feasibility of accounting in these terms has been lacking, and we have tried
 - xix - to provide it both in previous studies and in the text which is prefaced by these remarks. Our present study differs from its antecedents on two counts which go beyond the learning-by-doing of successive tasks and a maturing admiration of the statistician's craft. Both require some comment in anticipation of the discussion in the main text. First, we hold firmly to the proposition that data systems require a coherent view of the causality and interdependences within the structures they attempt to calibrate. In effect a model is needed to define what is relevant for empirical measurement, just as the measurements themselves are essential to quantitative analysis. In this sense both action and reaction are involved in an attempt to decide which dimensions of reality the national accounts should measure. Equally, the taxonomies or disaggregations which are adopted for each dimension are a variable to be determined through a perspective on which distinctions are important and those that are less so. Such issues arise immediately from our starting point of concern for the living standards of different socioeconomic groups. How are such groups to be defined, and in what terms should their living standards be measured? Beyond this we have questions about the causality which lies behind the determination of living standards, which lead us to query a commodity basis as the only criterion for disaggregation of production activity. Even though we lack a fully articulated model of how living standards are determined for different socioeconomic groups, our perception of the relevant taxonomies has evolved through successive studies and therefore affects the approach we have adopted here. By no means are all questions which might be asked addressed, let alone resolved, in this study. Indeed, to a considerable extent we are obliged to
 - xx - inherent taxonomies which derive from models other than our own, simply because they are the only ones available to us. But it remains the case that the present study has an advantage over earlier work insofar as it can draw on the experience of parallel developments in modeling activity which have been taking place over recent years. A second area of advantage for the present study lies in the choice of Malaysia as the subject of our investigation. There are many aspects to this,. but we would like to stress two at this point.  -1 - CHAPTER 1 INTRODUCTION 1.1 Background to the Study The subject of this study is the design and construction of an economic data framework for Malaysia which provides a suitable basis for policy analysis and, in particular, a basis for the investigation of employment and income distribution issues. As such, it is part of a broader analysis which addresses these questions both from the point of view of data systems and in terms of economic models L/ However, to the extent that there are a wide class of models which are consistent with this data framework, the latter is not dependent on any particular model formulation. Moreover, it is felt that this study may contribute something in its own right towards a new approach to macroeconomic accounting for developing countries, and therefore is worth presenting as a separate study which attempts to explain both the design and compilation of the data framework, and some of the thinking that lies behind it. The origins of national income accounting have been admirably traced by Stone_2/ as far back as the 17th century and to Gregory King, who estimated various economic magnitudes relating to England for the year 1688. Although several significant developments occurred in the 19th century with regard to 1/ This wider approach is introduced in Pyatt, G. and E. Very rapid developments began to take place after this time, with national income statistics being compiled for several countries. Stone identifies a most important landmark as the meeting of a group of statistical experts at the League of Nations, to discuss the measurement of the national income and the construction of social accounts. Their report 1-/ published by the United Nations in 1947, contained a recommendation that the estimation of the national income be set within a social accounting framework, and also included a suggested design for such a system. Following this first system, there have been others devised under the auspices of major international organizations,2/ the latest being the United Nations System of National Accounts,3/ often referred to as the new SNA. This was published in 1968 and remains as the most authoritative and widely used manual of social accounting in existence today. Quite apart from its rigorous methodological content, which is widely referred to by government statisticians in the Western world for social accounting definitions of the 1/ United Nations. Certainly this feature is less widely exploited than the definitional content of the SNA. The SNA approach is based upon a social accounting matrix framework first introduced by Stone and his associates1/ as a basis for a highly disaggregated computable model of the UK economy. The social accounting matrix (SAM) has been generalized in the SNA document so as to be broadly applicable to any nation which is reasonably advanced statistically. However, in spite of this, its applicability has typically been confined to the developed world, since most developing countries have a limited statistical capability and few are in a position to produce sets of social accounts which are as demanding as the SNA, taken in its entirety. In many ways one could argue that the apparent failure of the SNA as a statistical system of universal applicability is due to a misinterpretation of its aims. Instead of being seen as a system capable of consolidation and aggregation so as to highlight particularly important features of any given economic system, the SNA approach has been avoided if it cannot be carried out to the rote. From this basis, it is hardly surprising that use of the SNA has, in these cases, been confined to its value as a definitional manual. This is perhaps the most charitable explanation of the failure to fully adopt the SNA in the developing world. A less favorable view would simply be that it is inappropriate in is present form to cater for the special problems of many of these countries. Indeed, one could draw some support for this view from the fact that a short chapter on the adaptation of the full 1/ Cambridge, Department of Applied Economics (1962-).
 system to developing countries is couched within terms of being 'suggestions' rather than 'guidelines', thereby indicating that perhaps the special problems of doing so may yet have to be fully worked out. At the same time it can be said that while statistical systems remain weak in most developing countries, one reason for this is that they often adopt a piecemeal approach. If the SAM approach on which the SNA is based were to be seized on as the basic framework for developing economic statistics, then there is every chance that the data for developing countries would be more reliable, extensive, and meaningful. Alongside the historical developments in statistical methodology, new visions and objectives have since emerged for the developing world in particular. Certainly, at the inception of social accounting in the 1940's -- and some would argue even as recently as a decade ago -- economic policy objectives centered around the maximization of key aggregates such as gross national product or per capita GNP. A prime requirement for servicing and monitoring such policy is the derivation of sets of fairly aggregative national income accounts. Nowadays there is more widespread recognition and acceptance of distributional objectives for development, and such highly aggregative accounts of the macroeconomy are largely, if not totally, inadequate for this purpose. To support the new objectives far more detail is necessary, involving multi-way disaggregations of major aggregates in order to evaluate the effects of change on individual groups or sectors, no matter whether such change is truly exogenous or policy-induced within the system. And the limitations of summary national accounts are not simply confined to the problems of insufficient detail. It is easy to conceptualize that the economic data system ought to accommodate certain imputations beyond those already included as accepted convention. For example, in portraying the
 - 5 - distribution of income across various groups and classes of recipient, institutional transfers (particularly from government) could reflect certain benefits in kind, such as health care, education and welfare services 1. In short, statistical practices may be unnecessarily constrained by obsolete conventions, designed to service objectives of yesteryear and no longer appropriate to the needs of new development strategies. One purpose of this study is to illustrate an approach to macroeconomic data frameworks which hopefully will further contribute towards a redirection of future statistical efforts. Its roots are firmly based in the SNA and, in particular, the display of social accounts in matrix form. But there is more to it than this, including further justification for a view suggested by earlier country studies, viz., that reconciliation of apparently dissimilar data can be carried further than is usually entertained by utilizing the constraints inherent in a social accounting matrix framework. Thus more data sources can be deployed and more detailed disaggregations can be sustained to provide a richer, more illuminating data base for policy analysis than national accounts can usually convey. Not least, within our system we can answer the important question of: "Who gets what out of the national product?" And the answer is tied into the more conventional issues of production structure, balance of payments, savings/investment, etc. Accordingly, from our approach we hope to begin to understand distributional issues as an integral part of economic development and strategy, and not as a mere appendage. 1/ Of particular interest is a study undertaken by Meerman, in which he attempted to impute and value and identify the beneficiaries of certain government services in Malaysia. See Meerman (1978) and (1980).
 -6- 1.2 Nature and Significance of a SAM A social accounting matrix (SAM) can be considered as a particular representation of a set of double entry accounts for an economic system. However, instead of being shown in double entry form, the accounts are arranged so that they represent the rows and columns of a matrix; by convention, receipts (incomings) are shown along the rows, and payments (outgoings) down the columns. A cell entry in the matrix relates to a particular transaction or transfer within the economy. The column in which it is placed shows the account from which the flow originates, whilst the account to which it is destined is identified by the row. It follows that one precondition for a set of social accounts to be represented in matrix form is that they must be fully articulated: that is, each entry must appear in one account as a credit and some other account as a debit. In the SAM representation, however, each transaction or transfer appears once only, where the appropriate cell entry simultaneously shows the crediting and debiting accounts. It is clear that the matrix representation of a complete system of social accounts owes much to the input-output approach to the structural interdependence of production in the economy. However, a SAM extends this rather restricted domain of interdependence to embrace other interconnections within the macroeconomic system. Interrelations are generally identified between and within four basic groups of accounts: domestic institutions' current accounts; the corresponding capital accounts for institutions; production accounts; and accounts relating to transactions with the rest of the world. These are the four basic groups of accounts which are contained in most accounting systems. By implication, a fundamental SNA premise -- that
 accounts can be divided into current and capital accounts, with a complementary relationship existing between the two -- ip being maintained. Ihe distinction between current and capital accounts is defined here with the usual reference to an accounting period of one year. Furthermore, since institutions are the only bodies with the legal right of ownership, only they can save and accumulate. Institutions' accounts are therefore divided into separate current and capital accounts, as are those for the rest of the world which is treated as an additional 'institution.' The production accounts, on the other hand, do not divide in this way: their role is to embrace the accounts of the various production activities which generate value added, and of the factors of production which provide services employed by production activities. Departures from the SNA in our SAM approach to an information system for Malaysia can largely be ascribed to differences in classification, disaggregation, and arrangement of the matrix and its data. In some instances omissions are forced upon us; for example, our information system is made up entirely of flows and excludes balance sheet entries. This is clearly far from ideal. One implication is that, while the data system can identify several manifestations of income distribution, it contains no direct information on the distribution of asset ownership or wealth within the economy. The incorporation of such detail remains as a target for some future SAM exercise."Y 1/ The conceptual issues involved are discussed in the SNA and, as an extension of the present approach, in Pyatt and Thorbecke, op. cit.

Whatever mix of development objectives is chosen as the basis for policy -- involving growth, redistribution, employment and elimination of poverty -- the resulting composite objective is inevitably bound up with the living standards of individuals. This in turn translates into the supply and demands for basic needs or wants and for supernumerary wants which can be satisfied at higher levels of incomel' Our system of accounts attempts to allow for this by commencing (in row and column 1) with a display of demands for basic and supernumerary wants by households. In principle these wants should relate to requirements of items such as food, clothing, housing, education, leisure, and so on. In a fully developed system, therefore, wants would embrace rather more than consumers' expenditure, and would involve certain imputations of benefits, e.g. from public expenditure, if the SAM is to be expressed in money terms. However, for the present, such imputations are an ideal that has yet to be achieved, so that the cell entry in the first row of Table 1.1 refers quite simply to a set of expenditures by households of various types upon various categories of consumer goods and services. The demands for these wants (in row 1) are then met by supplies of commodities (in column 1). These mappings illustrate the functional use of a SAM as both an informational and an analytical device. The framework ensures complete consistency between demands for, and supplies of, commodities for household consumption; yet it preserves the classifications that are most meaningful to 1/ For an elaboration of this approach, see Pyatt and Thorbecke, op. cit.
 describe household wants (or the goods they buy) on the one hand, and the ultimate requirements from the pool of commodity supplies, on the other. The second class of accounts in Table 1.1 identify the receipt and disbursement of factor incomes within the economy. Factor income is derived both from domestic activities of production as well as from abroad. This is shown in the second row, whilst the allocation of this factor income between domestic institutions, and payments abroad of factor income, are shown down the second column. As with the wants accounts, there are many accounts implicit within the broad class of factor accounts. Factor incomes can be (and indeed are) disaggregated far beyond broad classes of returns to labor, rent on dwellings and return to capital in our empirical work. In particular, a substantial disaggregation according to the different types of labor required by production activities is thought to be especially useful in understanding the process by which labor demands are generated, and in matching these demands with the supplies of labor that are available. Moreover, households comprise individuals, who supply their labor (factor) services to production and in return receive incomes out of which households can satisfy their wants. The precise behavioural mechanisms are not discussed in this study, but we do attempt to provide a statistical picture of the details ofsuch linkages as a first step towards understanding their importance. Similarly we also consider it useful to distinguish different types of capital within the framework, the prime purpose being once more to identify the eventual recipients of profits that accrue to activities as a surplus of value added over payments to labor and rent on dwellings. One consequence of making these distinctions or disaggregations between factors is that the row account totals for each factor give a detailed view of the
 - 12 - functional, or factoral, distribution of income within the economy, while the column entries in the factor accounts spell out who receives these factor incomes. A feature of this detailed approach is that it retains full information on conventional aggregates. For example, Gross Domestic Product at factor cost is readily identifiable as the total value added of all production activities, whilst Gross National Product at factor cost is simply the row (or column) sum, net of factor payments made abroad. In Table 1.1 the current accounts for institutions are broadly split into three categories: households, corporate enterprises (companies) and government, in accordance with most conventional systems. Households and companies are the domestic institutional recipients of factor income, but in addition to this they also receive and disburse further amounts as transfer payments. A principal activity of government is to partake in this transfer or redistributive process, and in some economic systems can be viewed as assuming a major role. Government income is entirely non-factor (or transfer) income; receiving, for example, direct taxes and social security payments from households, direct taxes from private companies and operating surpluses of government-owned enterprises, as well as current transfers from abroad. This is matched by expenditures on commodities for government purposesl4/ as well as transfers to households (social security benefits, etc.), companies and the rest of the world. Households receive transfers from companies, in the form of distributed profits, as well as those from government. Furthermore, at a lower level of disaggregation, transfers of income may take place between 1/ It has previously been noted that it would be preferable to treat these items as government provision of wants for the various household groups.
 - 13 - various categories of household, and between categories of government. (For the types of economies currently being considered, inter-company transfers are less likely, although conceptually possible.) The result of accounting for all receipts of factoral income by institutions and of transfers (non-factor income) between institutions is a further manifestation of the distribution of income. In particular, the distribution of income between various types of household can be derived, given that each type is allowed a separate account within the overall schema. Nor need interesting disaggregations be confined to households. It may also be of interest to disaggregate the corporate sector according to ownership; for example, domestic versus foreign ownership. However, the prime distributional information appropriate to income and the institution accounts is likely to be centered around households, since this is ultimately bound up with the ability or inability of households to satisfy their wants, and hence with their living standards. One overall effect of extending and displaying a set of national accounts in the format of a social accounting matrix as in Table 1.1 is that flows within and between various parts of the economy can be recorded and followed through according to the processes that actually occur in the flux and flow of economic activity. It is for this reason that the 'Wants' and 'Factors' accounts are chosen to occupy the leading position in the matrix, relegating the engine room of the economic system, i.e. the production accounts (which are traditionally placed in the leading diagonal of a matrix of social accounts), to a less prominent location. The result is that the data system incorporates the translation of factoral incomes into household incomes and then, through wants, into demands on the production system through which factoral incomes are regenerated. The three dimensions in this mapping process -- (a) the factoral distribution of value added; (b) the household distribution of income; and (c) the structure of production between a set of production activities -- are all clearly distinguished and exemplified by the SAM. But these steps are also neatly subsumed within a complete system for the economy as a whole, so that overall consistency is maintained while recording the details of each linkage in the economic process.
 - 16 - This feature of a SAM framework -- that it provides a set of consistency constraints upon the various relationships within it -- is discussed in more detail at several points in subsequent chapters. For now it may suffice to point out that, aside from many compilational advantages, it is an important psychological feature not readily apparent in a conventional display. It explicitly engages the notion that every payment has a destination and every receipt an origin. Such an obvious feature can easily be overlooked in an accounting system which is not articulated in a matrix framework. As it is, such a framework proves to be an invaluable aid to the empirical estimation of the SAM, as well as defining and displaying the restrictions that must be placed upon whatever behavioural relationships describe the economic process by which the magnitudes are generated. 1.3 An Overview of the SAM Compilation for Malaysia In the previous section, certain advantages of the SAM approach to macroeconomic data frameworks have been argued. Although there appear to be decided advantages on conceptual grounds, particularly with regard to the potential for formal analysis and policy, there are also several advantages that arise from the purely statistical standpoint of making the best use of available data. In many ways Malaysia has proved to be an excellent country to study for utilization of the SAM approach. This section discusses some aspects of the overall application so as to set the scene for the more detailed description of sources and methods that is to follow in later chapters, and to contrast the Malaysia study with previous SAM studies which are its antecedents. It is well known that accounting data are generally of quite variable quality for many economic systems. This is particularly so for developing
 - 17 - countries where lacunae are fairly commonplace and injunctions to exercising extreme caution in using certain series ought often to be heeded. There is a well-rehearsed debate as to whether data of dubious quality is better or worse than no data at all. This is essentially meaningless outside a particular context and here we are concerned to note that in some real sense a social accounting matrix framework does provide many implicit, as well as explicit, constraints on the data which enter into it. Specifically, the framework sets bounds on the possible range certain values can take, given other entries in the table. Data cannot be retained in the framework independent of such consistency checks. This leads, therefore, to a substantial practical appeal for the consistency framework underlying the social accounting matrix in making partial use of data which may be otherwise inadequate. At the same time, it can also be noted that multiple estimates, almost as much as non- existent data, can be the bane of a planner's task. In some cases, reasons for multiple estimates can be readily explained by differing bases of measurement, for example,!/ but in other instances the differences arise because surveys have been carried out by more than one department. Either way (and there are many other possibilities), it is hard to concede that a rationalization of such inconsistent estimates can be detrimental to an overall understanding of the mechanism of the economy. At least, this is the spirit in which our SAM is constructed. At worst, it is simply a matter of crudely adjusting some data to accord with others. At best, sources are selected and details are fitted together so that the structure of the whole 1/ Examples are legion: common ones are calendar year as against financial year; trade statistics being collected according to shipment, receipt or even dates of invoicing.

In the text which follows, chapters are arranged so as to highlight the principal directions -- initially independent, but subsequently interdependent -- in which the compilation of a 1970 SAM for Peninsular Malaysia has proceeded. As already outlined in Section 1.3, the two principal directions for compiling the accounts have been via the Household accounts (using the Household Expenditure Survey data) and the Production accounts (based upon the published Input-Output tables). These two avenues are considered in Chapters 3 and 4. The Factor accounts provide an implicit link between the Household and Production accounts, and their consistency from the two sources is considered in Chapter 5. Meanwhile, the rationale for adopting certain classifications of factors and households is also discussed in Chapter 3. Chapter 6 accumulates all of the sources and methods for compiling the remaining and more aggregative accounts of the system. These include institutions' current accounts other than households.  - 46 - Reference has been made earlier in this chapter to the operation of consolidating two or more accounts within a SAM framework. This is the most important of the basic operations which can be imposed on a SAM, and involves three steps. First, the rows corresponding to the accounts to be consolidated are aggregated; and the results obtained are presented as a new row of the SAM corresponding to the consolidated account. Next, the corresponding columns are treated analogously. And finally, the element of the resulting SAM which lies at the intersection of the newly formed row and column for the consolidated account is set equal to zero. This is the substance of the process. Essentially it involves aggregation of a set of accounts by summing their incomes and outlays. The only novelty is in the third step whereby the diagonal entry in the newly formed account is set equal to zero. Since this is a diagonal entry, changing its value does not upset the row and column balance of the SAM. And, again because it is a diagonal, a non-zero entry measures transfer payments within the (consolidated) account in which it is located. Thus setting a diagonal entry to zero corresponds to the elimination of a particular type of transfer payment l It is immediately obvious that in the process of consolidation, the order of the first two steps is reversible. Thus in going from the implicit tableau of 212 rows and columns of our SAM to the aggregate SAM of eleven rows and columns in Table 2.1, we can start by combining either rows or columns.  - 55 - CHAPTER 3 HOUSEHOLD INCOME AND OUTLAY ACCOUNTS 3.1 Introduction As discussed in the previous chapter, one of our main concerns in moving forward from the aggregate SAM shown as Table 2.1 towards a more detailed data schema is to provide a quantitative picture of income differentials among different types of households. Such a picture records the distribution of income. It is therefore a partial answer to the important question: "Who gets what out of the national product?'Vl/ To distinguish the incomes of different household groups within a SAM clearly requires disaggregation of the household sector into different household types. Table 2.7 has already recorded the fact that, within the resident population, 32 different household types are distinguished in our analysis. It remains then to discuss the choice of disaggregation criteria which are involved. As a preliminary to this, there are some general issues which it is useful to rehearse 2/ In the first instance, the concern of development policy is with the standard of living of individuals, not with households or household groups. A 1/ Since the disposal of domestic product is partly at the discretion of companies and government as well as households, the "who gets what?" question is only partly answered by the details of income distribution among households. The distribution of disposable income between House- holds (in aggregate), Companies and Government is also a critical aspect of income distribution. See Pyatt (1977) for further development of this argument. 2/ The following discussion draws substantially on Pyatt and Thorbecke (1976).
 - 56 - conceptual possibility, therefore, would be to disaggregate the domestic (i.e. household) sector of the economy into individual as opposed to household types. In practice there are good reasons for not adopting such an approach. On the outlay side of the accounts, for many purposes the household acts as a collective spending unit, making essentially common provision for such basic items as food and shelter. More generally, within the household, the principle: "to each according to their needs", may have some proximate validity, so that living standards of individuals may be assumed to be roughly equal. And even if such a view is contentious (e.g. in terms of the respective living standards of men, women and children) there is little that can be done about it in practice since available data on expenditures treat the household as the primary unit. On the income side of the accounts, the situation is only partly different. Wage and salary payments typically accrue to individuals and can be recorded as such. But many households are engaged in domestic or unincorporated business enterprises. The tenant farmer may be individually responsible for his rental, but it is likely that several family members will be engaged in the farm work. Accordingly, the net income of the farm may be difficult to allocate among the individuals who produced it. These arguments imply that for practical purposes the household has to be the basic unit in the domestic sector. However, incomes have an important individual element so that the composition of a household in terms of individuals with different skills is a potentially important determinant of its general living standard. Equally, the household's endowment with assets, such as land, will also be of major importance. It follows that one dimension in which criteria for classifying households might be found is in terms of the factors of production with which they are endowed.
 - 57 - It also follows from these arguments that the criteria for grouping households cannot be considered independently of the criteria used to distinguish different factors of production: the two dimensions are interrelated and come together in our SAM as determinants of the sub-matrix T3.2 in which incomes of the different factors are paid out to each of the separately distinguished household types. The linkage between household types and factor classifications is important if we are to look behind the immediate quantitative answer to: "who gets what?" Since a further criterion for household groupings might be differences in their savings/consumption behaviour, it follows that redistribution of income between groups of households will change the observed aggregate expenditure patterns. It then follows that changes in income distribution will alter production patterns since the latter are determined in part by demand. However, if we are interested in the causes underlying the distribution of income, it must be recognized that the effects of income distribution on production structure are only part of the story. A change in production structure implies changes in the demand for factors of production. Hence changes in incomes of the factors can be expected as a consequence. And since factor incomes are a major determinant of household incomes, it follows that not only does income distribution affect production structure, but production structure will be a major element in determining income distribution. This two-way interdependence of income distribution and production structure is the basis of most recent modeling efforts to understand income distribution as an integral part of the development process. One of our main concerns in developing a SAM for Malaysia is to serve such modeling work. And
 - 58 - here it is worth noting that the sense in which this two-way interdependency can be captured must obviously depend on the way in which households, factors and production activities are classified: some classification schemes will capture more of the essential processes than others. In these terms, the grouping of households by income levels is not obviously the most attractive approach. It is clearly the most informative approach if the only issue is to describe income distribution at a point in time. But if the purpose of description is to provide a basis for diagnosis and policy change, then the grouping criteria should correspond to constituencies which can be influenced differentially by policy means. Deciles of the household income distribution are virtually impossible to legislate for as such. There is limited value, therefore, in a data framework which groups households according to an income criterion ./ Against this background our chosen criteria for grouping households are location, race and employment status with the following disaggrrgations according to each criterion: Location Race Employment Status FUrban1 Malay Employer Rural] x Chinese x Employee Indian Own Account Worker Other Other 2 4 4 1/ An earlier study of Sri Lanka (see Pyatt and Roe with Lindley, Round and others (1977)) classified households by (i) income level; and (ii) geographical location. They differ in recognizing employment status of the principal earner as a criterion for further disaggregation of households, while education level complements location and race as a disaggregation criterion for distinguishing individuals as a factor of production. The locational criterion for disaggregation is useful because the urban/rural distinction captures many aspects of duality. Depending on this distinction, individuals with otherwise similar characteristics are quite likely to be paid different wages, have different job opportunities and employment expectations, and generally to be subject to different sets of parameters in their socio-economic behaviour. In much the same way, for Malaysia it was considered important to distinguish four ethnic groups throughout the factor and household analyses. This is because the government's general economic development strategy includes specific concern for the distribution of employment opportunities, income and wealth between
 - 60 - the various ethnic groups.!/ Accordingly, in our classification scheme, the three principal ethnic groups of Malay, Chinese and Indian population members are supplemented by a group comprising all other races. This latter category raises some serious problems of sample size in analyzing househld survey data, especially since 'Others' are only about one percent of the Peninsular Malaysian Population. Accordingly, results for this group are subject to rather wide margins of error, which is the price for obtaining distinct figures for the three major racial groups. However, the combined location and race dimensions are important not only from the viewpoint of monitoring policies through their distributive effects, but also because they correspond to behavioural differences within the Malaysian economy, not least with respect to savings. Further behavioural differences are captured by using normal employment status of the principal earner as a third criterion for disaggregating households. For this purpose four employment status codes were used: Employer, Employee, Own Account Worker, and Other (which comprises students, housewives, retired persons, etc.). This classification goes some way towards capturing differences in life style and assets among household types which have quite different relationships with factor markets according to this criterion. The education dimension which complements location and race in defining labor types turns out to be important in explaining income differences. Ideally each type of labor ought to be defined so that it can be viewed as providing a homogeneous factor service irrespective of the 1/ See, for example, Government of Malaysia (1976).
 - 61 - production activity in which it is employed. Adding education level to the list of criteria for defining labor types goes a good way towards reaching this ideal. Of course, payments for labor services are not the only type of income which households receive. Owner occupiers receive imputed rent on their houses as well as actual rental income.1/ Additionally, current transfer incomes are important both for the richer households which receive interest and dividends on their financial assets, and for the poorer households which may be largely dependent on remittances. The employment status dimension of the household classification potentially captures some of this variety. Similarly, income from unincorporated business enterprises tends to be concentrated in employer and own account households. In Chapter 4 an attempt is made to split this income into a profit component and a part which can be treated as an imputed wage. This is one of the most difficult parts of our exercise but also most useful in attempting to understand the sources of income inequality. Before coming to this discussion of factor accounts in Chapter 4, the present chapter focuses on results for household incomes and outlays. The starting point is data from a household survey and is discussed in the next section, Section 3.2. Then Section 3.4 attempts further refinement of the results obtained up to this point. This has three aspects.  - 85 - CHAPTER 4 FACTOR INCOME AND OUTLAY ACCOUNTS 4.1 The Role of Factor Accounts Factors are represented by the accounts number 2 in our schematic SAM (Table 2.1). As discussed in the introduction to the previous chapter, our objective is to disaggregate factors into 48 different labor types and three types of capital, viz. unincorporated business capital, corporate business capital, and housing. It follows that there are 51 different factors of production in the SAM for Peninsular Malaysia. The main role of factor accounts is apparent from Table 1.1: they receive value added from production activities (in return for factor services), and then distribute this factor income to different institutions according to their contributions to factor supplies. These are the main mappings which will concern us in this chapter. However, it is clearly possible to envisage a SAM in which there are no factor accounts so that value added is paid directly to institutions by the production accounts. Indeed this is the procedure adopted in one of our earlier SAMs.i/ The question must therefore be asked whether factor accounts are valuable as a separate dimension of the SAM. I/ See Pyatt et al., 'Methodology for Macro-Economic Projections', Working Paper No. 12, ILO. Comprehensive employment strategy mission to Iran, ILO, Geneva (1972). This study is also discussed in Chapter 5 of Blitzer, Clark and Taylor, Economy-wide Models and Development Planning (1975), and in Pyatt and Round, 'Social Accounting Matrices in Development Planning' (1977). Emphasis in the former is on macro- economic models while the latter focusses more on statistical issues.
 - 86 - The answer to the above question can be negative if interest is restricted to an ex post determination of 'who gets what' out of the national product. In this context full information is provided by disaggregated accounts for institutions. Retention of accounts for Wants then supplements data on the distribution of income across institutions by giving details of consumption levels and the extent to which different wants are satisfied. Similarly, in the absence of factor accounts, payments of value added directly to households would constitute their primary source of income, and hence the inter-relationship between production structure and income distribution would remain explicit. Thus the elimination of factor accounts from the SAM would not undermine its role in bringing issues of equity into the major economic data framework. The main reason for wanting to retain factor accounts and, by extensive disaggregation, to give them far more emphasis than is usual, is that two distinct mechanisms are at work in generating the mapping of income flows from production to households. By routing these flows through factor accounts, we achieve a separation of these issues and hence a basis for understanding them in a causal sense. The two steps in the linkage are from production activities to factors, and then from factors to institutions. The first involves the mechanisms of factor markets, and especially employment. Through them the factoral distribution of income is determined. And while economic theory is some way from a concensus on how the factoral distribution is determined, there is a substantial body of literature to draw on in approaching the issues which, meanwhile, are well defined. The second step is from the factoral distribution of income to the distribution across institutions, and notably
 - 87 - across household types. This second mapping is essentially determined by the distribution of wealth if we include labor skills as a form of capital. Thus the relative endowments of different household types with respect to a particular factor will determine their relative shares of that factor's income. No other issues are involved if the factor disaggregations justify the assumption that each factor market is without imperfections. This clearly raises the question of how factor markets are subdivided. But setting that aside for a moment, the importance of wealth (defined to include human skills) as a fundamental determinant of living standards is made explicit by the SAM format when factor accounts are included in the framework. This not only emphasizes the importance of initial conditions in determining income distribution but also provides an entree to dynamic considerations whereby current patterns of savings and investment change the distribution of wealth over time and hence determine income distribution in the longer term. The distribution of wealth, including human capital, is the basis for the mapping from factors to households given the assumption that individual factor markets are homogeneous. This assumption, and the mapping itself, suggests that the choice of classifications for disaggregating factors is important and needs to be considered in relation to the household and other institution classifications. This same point has been made in the introduction to Chapter 3 where both household and labor classification criteria are discussed. As reported there, we have chosen to adopt a three- way disaggregation of labor based on:

Table 4.4 serves by way of an illustration of the general method which we adopted. The table has two panels; panel (a) records the number of income earners who receive unincorporated business income only, again according to household type and educational level of the individual. The second panel, (b), simply records the total unincorporated business income received by all individuals of the labor type in question. This includes the unincorporated business income received by individuals who also receive basic wages. The problem faced at this stage is to draw off some of the unincorporated business income in the lower panel as imputed wages for the income earners in the upper panel. What is then left as a residual in the lower panel is a measure of income from unincorporated business capital, i.e. the surplus generated by unincorporated businesses operated by different types of households after subtracting off an imputed wage income component. This general objective is achieved in three steps as follows: (i) The lower panel of Table 4.4 is scaled upwards by a factor of 3.208 to obtain consistency with the National Accounts. This scaling factor is taken from Table 3.1. (ii) Imputed wages are subtracted from the result of (i) so as to bring wage earnings by employers up to the level of employees as previously discussed.
 - 102 - (iii) An imputed wage matrix is subtracted from the result of (ii). This matrix is essentially derived from the upper panel of Table 4.4 using some appropriately derived row and column multipliers which stand proxy for estimated average imputed wage rates. These multipliers are applied to the data in panel (a) to estimate the imputed wage rate. The result is then an estimated matrix for unincorporated business profit for Urban-Malay households. Replicating the exercise for other household types yields a complete picture of unincorporated business profit receipts. Details of factor wage incomes received by household type can then be obtained by adding the actual basic wage matrix (i.e. Table 4.1(b)), scaled by 2.913 to obtain consistency with the national accounts) to the two matrices which are subtracted from incorporated business incomes in steps (ii) and (iii) above. In other words, basic wages plus imputed wages yield total wages.  - 105 - If a similar assumption is made to impute a wage for those workers in Employee households who receive only unincorporated business incomes and no wages, then the consequence for all of the Malay and Indian households (but not fet-all Chinese households) would be implied negative profit income from unincorporated businesses. This clearly suggests that the proposed imputed wage is too high. And this is to be expected on a priori grounds. In Employee households the main earner has the usual status 'Employee' and will earn a wage. Accordingly, those who are not earning wages will not be main earners and therefore will earn less than the main earner. It follows that a lower wage from that of the main earner must be imputed to them. The chosen imputed wage is the same as that imputed to workers in Own Account households who do not earn wages. The reason for this assumption is that such workers earn only unincorporated business income and the market value of their labor services is not affected by whether the main earner in their household is an Employee or an Own Account worker. Therefore, the shadow price which attaches to the labor serviles of those who do not work for wages is taken as being the same for the two groups. Summary of household wage income calculations These methods of wage imputation can be summarized as follows. The analysis has distinguished 384 different types of workers corresponding to 48 labor types (location, race and education level); the usual employment status of the principal income earner for the household in which the worker resides (4 groups); and a distinction between workers who earn basic wages and those who do not (and therefore receive only incorporated business income). For all workers who actually earn basic wages, a predicted average wage has been calculated and is given by the product of the appropriate r and s variables shown in Tables 4.2 and 4.3. The estimates of actual and imputed
 - 106 - wages are then built up according to the schema set out in Table 4.6. One way of looking at Table 4.6 is to ignore the difference between predicted and actual wages. Workers then fall into three groups. (a) All workers in Employer households and basic wage earners in Employee households are imputed the average wage of the latter. Since this involves an r factor of 1.0 these wages are given (exactly or approximately) by the s variables in Table 4.3. For the second and third group of workers, the wage rate is given by the product of the same s factors and a factor r which is not equal to one. (b) For all workers in Own Account households and those in Employee households who are not basic wage earners, the r factor used is the one derived for basic wage earners in Own Account households. In other words, households in this category have their actual average wage or, if they are not basic wage earners, the average wage of those in Own Account households who do earn basic wages. (c) Finally, those in Other households who earn only unincorporated business income are imputed the average wage of those in such households who do earn basic wages. In this way, and ignoring the distinction between a predicted and average wage, each of 384 types of workers has, or is assumed to have, one of 144 (= 3 x 48) different average wage rates.

Moreover, there is no allowance for individuals working part-time in an unincorporated business and part-time for wages. These are all major limitations. However, there can be two justifications for stopping the analysis at this stage. One is that at some point the problems of sample size become insuperable, and effects beyond those for location, race, education and employment status of principal earner are increasingly difficult to discern. A second argument is that, in some general sense, the results obtained at the present stage appear to be reasonable. Since elements of the matrix are numbers of people and not financial flows, there are no constraints imposed on the manpower matrix from previous calculations or national accounts. However, it is apparent that a
 - 110 - wage rate multiplied by an element of the manpower matrix yields a financial flow in terms of the total wage payment to a particular type of labor by a particular activity. Thus the manpower matrix underlies that part of the mapping from activities to factor payments which relates to wages; and the wage rates paid provide the missing link. The manpower matrix to be estimated here has dimensions 48 x 31. The row dimension corresponds to the 48 types of labor previously discussed, while the column dimension refers to 30 distinct production activities plus a further column to record numbers unemployed. Thus the total labor force, by type of labor, is given by row sums, including unemployed rather than just the numbers currently employed. The 30 different production activities distinguished in our analysis have been enumerated in Chapter 2 1/, while the next chapter gives some further details on their relationship with input-output and national accounts classifications. Here they will simply be taken as given, although at the end of this chapter we comment on desirable classification criteria for production activities in the light of our general approach. While details of the manpower matrix are not constrained by any financial statistics, our procedure has been one more to base details on the HES Survey but to modify these within control figures provided by other data sources. In the present case, the control data sources are the 1970 Population Census and the details of employment and unemployment in 1970 provided by the Third Malaysia Plan (TMP). 1/ See Table 2.9.

In facing up to them - admittedly guess;timating numbers on occasion and more generally forcing consistency - we hope to have shown the feasibility of grafting detailed income and outlay accounts onto national accounts which have been derived via a commodity balance approach. We suggest that the exercise might have been easier if a
 - 123 - SAM approach to national accounts had been adopted at the outset, but evidence on this must lie in the future. Meanwhile some attempt has been made to suggest appropriate criteria for disaggregation of Factors and Institutions. We now address the question of how the Production classification might be structured. Since our conceptual approach to these accounts differs quite fundamentally from SNA methodology, discussion of the differences precedes the numerical presentation and provides much of the subject matter of this section and Sections 5.2 and 5.3 also. Accounts which provide a data basis for input-output analysis are a component part of any SAM. Indeed, as mentioned in the introduction to this report, the matrix approach to social accounting may be considered, at least in part, to be an outgrowth from the input-output system and its historical antecedents. The most elementary treatment of the balance of demand and supply for different commodities in the economy is characterized by the situation where the production accounts simply comprise a set of accounts for each industry. In this case a one-to-one correspondence is defined between industries and their products, so that all of the domestic supply of a commodity comes from a particular industry. The principal drawback with this approach is that the correspondence between industries and their products is not always one-to-one; that is to say, industries frequently produce more than one product, no matter how the industry classification is defined. The SNA has adopted a convention, first developed by Stone for the Cambridge Growth Model41/ of distinguishing between industries and the 1/ Cambridge, Department of Applied Economics (1962-), Vol. 1.
 - 127 - commodities which they produce. In this approach the classifications used to define industries are usually the same as those used to classify commodities. Production establishments are then grouped into industries according to whichever commodity group their principal product(s) fall within. In such a system there are just as many industries as there are commodities; industries produce mainly the commodities from which they take their name; and there is secondary production by each industry of commodities other than the principal product. This approach has been relaxed in our Malaysia SAM to allow greater flexibility in the definition of industries and commodities. Our starting point is to group production establishments into production activities rather than into industries defined by the products produced. This allows several flexibilities in determining the flows in the production accounts. Not least of these is the ability to classify establishments according to their technological or institutional characteristics (for example, small-scale as opposed to large-scale, or formal/informal, etc.) rather than exclusively according to the commodities they produce. The distinction still allows secondary productionl/ to be embraced within the accounting system, as will shortly be seen. Thus, activities can still produce more than one commodity, just as each commodity can be produced by more than one activity. Meanwhile, our scheme allows different activities to produce the same commodity, but in different ways.  - 147 - The costs have nothing to do with data collection since SNA SAM and Market Price SAM require the same basic information, i.e. the same numbers need to be collected in each case since surveys and censuses can only obtain reliable information on actual transactions, i.e. on transactions at market prices. It follows that in practice computation of SNA SAM begins implicitly with Market Price SAM and then goes through the manipulations which have been described in the previous section. This suggests an advantage for Market Price SAM in avoiding some of this manipulative work. The advantage of SNA SAM over Market Price SAM is that the former can involve fewer commodities. To take an example, rice which is consumed by cultivator households must be treated in Market Price SAM as a separate commodity to rice which is sold in the urban market. Both types of rice can be assumed to start out as the same good. But rice for the urban market requires additional inputs from the transport sector to move it to an urban area, and further inputs from Distribution to channel it through to retail outlets. Thus one would expect rice in urban markets to cost more and, from the point of view of production inputs, it is a different commodity to the rice which a cultivator does not market but rather retains for consumption by his family. In this example, from the point of view of Market Price SAM we have two distinct commodities which require separate treatment. But for SNA SAM both types of rice are the same and therefore can be included in a common account. This is because two commodities are identical in SNA SAM if they are the same in basic values, i.e. if the differences between them are attributable to differences in Trade and Transport' inputs.'''The advantage of SNA SAM is therefore that the commodity accounts within it are simpler.

These facts, and especially the latter, explain why statistics for East Malaysia in 1970 are relatively rudimentary. In fact great strides have been made in the past few years towards statistical coverage on a par with that for the West. Integrated National Accounts are now being generated. But for 1970, which is the base year for the Second Malaysian Plan, the integration has not been attempted in published sources and basic data for East Malaysia are relatively sparse. In the next chapter we attempt to produce a social accounting matrix for 1970 for the whole of Malaysia. This inevitably involves an attempt to build a SAM picture for the Eastern States and provides the subject matter for the present chapter. It involves working with data which are limited both in coverage and consistency. Accordingly it presents a rather different set of issues to those faced in constructing a SAM for Peninsular Malaysia as discussed in previous chapters. And, in fact, the problems would have been insuperable were we not prepared to 'borrow' details from our results for West Malaysia to fill in lacunae in the source material for the East. From one point of view, the need to borrow data from West Malaysia in filling out detailed accounts for the East suggests an interesting perspective for the present exercise. Specifically, since few countries are comparable to

The 'borrowing' of coefficients which has been a basis for the estimation when direct information is lacking is an admittedly crude procedure so that the derived estimates laust be considered as initial approximations only. However, this is not to say that the estimates are worthless. On the contrary, they bring together what is known about East Malaysia in terms of macroeconomic data and fill out these facts in a way which is arguably sensible. To the extent that this is successful, a more detailed picture of East Malaysia begins to emerge. And where difficulties or discrepancies arise, an obvious focus for future statistical priorities is clearly identified. While one might look ultimately for data on East Malaysia which is as rich as that for the West, the view lie have formed as a result of our investigations is that the availability of new primary data on relatively few activities and commodities could enhance the overall quality of the results considerably. It can also be pointed out that the 'borrowing' of data as illustrated here is not such a cavalier step as some purists might maintain. In this context, the fact that economic modellers are 'borrowing' data all the time is hardly a strong defense. But it is'more to the point to cite common practice in national accounts compilations Few countries collect annual information on inter-industry transactions. Intervals of three or four years
 - 211 - are more common, to which periods of one or two years must be added to allow for the time taken in data processing. Hence national accounts compilation may rely on an input-output table which is up to five years out of date. In an economy growing at seven percent per annum the rules of compound interest imply that there has been growth of 50 percent between the base year of the input-output table and its application to obtain consistency of commodity balances for national accounts purposes. In comparison, our borrowings of data may involve margins of error which are comparable as opposed to being of a different order of magnitude. While the borrowing of data can be defended to a degree in the above terms, there remains the choice of methods for reconciling such extraneous estimates with the known facts for East Malaysia. Our procedures are admittedly arrived at through judgement and trial and error. Others would prefer more formal procedures. These are becoming availablel/ and an interesting comparison might be made between the methods we have used and a more objective approach. Equally, there are alternative subjective methods and more than one formal approach has been suggested. Experience with alternatives could provide a useful subject for future research. Meanwhile, each approach recognizes the need to reconcile data from sources which have different degrees of reliability. The problem is therefore to make the best use of available data as a complementary step toward having better primary data. While the present exercise has stopped at the point of having disaggregated production accounts for commodities and activities, it would in 1/ See Byron (1978).
