 - 214 - CHAPTER 8 A SAM FOR ALL MALAYSIA 8.1 Regional and National Accounts The previous chapters have shown how SAMs can be constructed from available data sources for both East and West Malaysia. The sources for West Malaysia are substantially better than those for East Malaysia, both in terms of coverage and quality of data. This difference is largely explained in historical terms. Only since 1963 have the Eastern States of Sabah and Sarawak joined the Federation, and their statistical services, although continually undergoing improvements, are still less advanced than those for the Peninsular States. The perspective in previous chapters has been to consider East Malaysia and West Malaysia as distinct economies. However, an obvious change in perspective sees them as distinct regions of the same economy, i.e. as All Malaysia or, simply, Malaysia. This re-orientation provides the subject matter of the present chapter which is therefore concerned with the integration of the separate SAMs for the two regions, leading ultimately to a SAM for Malaysia as a whole. The issues raised are not trivial and we can note at this early stage that generation of an All Malaysia SAM is not simply a matter of aggregation. A SAM approach to regional accounting schemes gives emphasis to structural connections and hence to the linkages between regional components. This implies that in order to derive a SAM for All Malaysia, we must give detailed consideration to the transactions between the two economies. In the first instance, this involves a disaggregation of the
 - 215 - external transactions for each economy (region) into transactions between East and West Malaysia (interregional transactions), and transactions by each region with other parts of the world. However, it should be noted that in the particular case which concerns us, the situation as it exists between the two regions of Malaysia is complicated by the position of Singapore as an entrepot for a variety of commercial activities. A good deal of merchandise trade between East and West Malaysia is still routed through Singapore, while its position as a financial and commercial center means that many non-merchandise transactions and monetary transfers are cleared through Singapore financial intermediaries. In consequence, there are very real difficulties in distinguishing actual East/West flows as opposed to those which involve the :Lntermediation of Singapore. For our purposes here we have generally assumed that estimates provided by the Department of Statistics in Kuala Lumpur have somehow managed to reconcile such difficulties. While the identification of actual interregional transctions is a major issue, there are in addition some conceptual problems in the design of a SAM schema to accommodate a regional dimension. Thus in the next section, Section 8.2, we discuss the problems of obtaining consistent data on interregional transactions from available sources; while Section 8.3 discusses the subsequent conceptual issue of how this data should be presented. Both topics are of some general interest. With respect to consistent data it can be noted that in order to obtain a SAM for All Malaysia, it is necessary first to split the external accounts for each region into that part which represents transfers within the All Malaysia context, and that part which represents transactions with other parts of the world. In effect, the previous Rest of World accounts within each regional SAM have to be disaggregated. And it can be noted that the methods for doing so illustrate an option within the SAM
 - 216 - framework which is independent of the ultimate goal of producing an All Malaysia SAM. This is simply to achieve a disaggregation of the external accounts of an economy to show separately the links with different international trading or financing partners. Many countries are already developing their Balance of Payments statistics in this direction since there are obvious policy implications to be derived from differences in the pattern of external transactions with different currency areas, countries in different stages of development, or different economic or political blocs. The SAM format can accommodate these distinctions with no extra difficulties to those which attend an attempt to disaggregate Balance of Payments data on such a basis. The disaggregation of external transactions for East or West Malaysia illustrates the point. While trade between East and West Malaysia is a component of external transactions for both regions, it is not an external transaction for All Malaysia. Accordingly such interregional trade must be netted out to obtain external accounts for All Malaysia. This requires that it should be estimated consistently from the point of view of both regions if the data are to be reconciled. To do so is not a trivial matter since the problem is more complex than the need to arrive at a common set of figures given alternative initial estimates. Additionally there is a conceptual problem which derives from the treatment of commodity flows from West to East Malaysia as exports at f.o.b. prices from the West Malaysian point of view; and as imports at c.i.f. prices from the point of view of East Malaysia. The distinction is analogous to that between factor and basic prices as discussed in Chapter 5 and the treatment of it in Section 8.3 is fundamental to a regional accounting scheme. The crux of the matter is to recognize that essentially similar commodities may be traded in different markets. In this case the markets differ according
 - 217 - to location, and delivery charges have to be accounted for. Obviously, our starting point was the separate SAMs for East and West Malaysia. However, the problem is a general one which is inherent in any attempt to derive a SAM by combining SAMs for different economies. While consistency in the treatment of interregional commodity flows is sufficient to obtain an All Malaysia SAM with detailed commodity accounts, there is an obvious interest in an All Malaysia SAM which retains a regional disaggregation within the accounts. There are several alternative formats within which this can be done,l/ corresponding to more or less exacting demands for primary data. The one we favor is among the least demanding in its data needs. It is presented in Section 8.4 as an intermediate step towards a final, aggregate SAM for All Malaysia. To obtain it, we have first generated the extended multi-regional SAM shown as Table 8.1. In introducing the SAM set out as Table 8.1 it should be noted first that the accounts within it can be viewed as comprising three principal blocks of accounts. One block relates to East Malaysia; the second to West Malaysia, and the third to the Rest of the World.  - 219 - Each of the blocks of accounts for East and West Malaysia contain nine separate accounts. These are the nine domestic accounts previously shown in the aggregate SAMs for East and West Malaysia, i.e. they exclude the external accounts for each region (accounts 7 and 8). In this new format, 'Rest of World' has the same definition from the point of view of both regions. Transactions with it are shown bordering Table 8.1 and are labelled as accounts 7* and 8* in recognition that the definition of 'Rest of World' is now different. A consequence of representing the accounts in the format of Table 8.1 is that transactions between the domestic accounts for East Malaysia on the one hand, and those for West Malaysia on the other, appear as diagonal entries in off-diagonal partitions of the table. This emphasizes their interregional transfer characteristic. The sources and derivation of these interregional transfers will be discussed in the next section. For now the point to note is that their location in Table 8.1 implies that interregional transfers are simultaneously shown as an outgoing from an account in one region and as an incoming to the same account in the other region. Not all accounts have! interregional transfers associated with them, however. The Wants accounts (number 1) simply define a mapping between household requirements and the commodities they ultimately demand; and this mapping is fundamentally without a geographical dimension. Commodities may be traded interregionally, but Wants are not, so the elements at the intersection of Wants account, East with West, are defintionally zero. So too are the interregional transfers associated with Activities and Indirect Taxes (accounts 10 and 11). These are strictly 'within region' accounts: Activities are engaged only in the production of commodities, and as such do not interact with external accounts;
 - 220 - similarly, the Indirect Tax accounts serve only as an account for collecting such taxes and their eventual payment to government. For all other accounts potentially there are some interregional transfers, although of course some of these may actually be zero because no actual transfers are recorded. The essence of the treatment of interregional transfers in our SAM is that geographical flows are distinguished from functional flows. More specifically, all transactions between accounts are represented as taking place within each region, so that interregional transfers simply augment the receipts of an account in one region and simultaneously deplete the same account in the other region. In Table 8.1 the East to West and West to East blocks of elements are set out so that interregional transfers, including actual zero flows (represented by zeros) form the diagonal elements. Since gross flows are being represented, there are instances in which an East to West transaction takes place at the same time as a comparable flow in the opposite direction. There is a precise correspondence between the entries in Table 8.1 and the aggregate SAMs for East and West Malaysia previously presented in Tables 7.3 and 2.1 respectively. For the most part this correspondence is straightforward: for all transactions other than those with accounts 7, 8 and 9, the entries in Table 8.1 have a one-to-one correspondence with an entry in Table 2.1 or Table 7.1. Thus, for example, savings of East Malaysian institutions are shown as receipts by East Malaysian capital accounts (number 6) of 196.8 from households, 106.6 from companies, and 36.8 from government, as before. Similar receipts by West Malaysian capital accounts are shown in the second block of accounts, again as income for account number 6, but this time from West Malaysian institutions.

By the time these same goods arrive in the commodity markets of West Malaysia, their value will be increased to the extent that there are freight and insurance charges involved in moving them. Such charges for the flow of goods from East to West will be denoted by e(E + W) , w(E + W) and

 - 237 - For interregional trade the distinction between the data in Tables 8.8 and 8.9 is strictly analogous to that between commodity transactions at basic versus market prices as discussed in Chapter 5. Thus exports in the interregional context record merchandise commodity flows excluding freight and insurance charges, which are separately shown as an aggregate export of the commodity group(s) which supply insurance and freight services. On the import side, however, the freight and insurance services are included in the valuation of the merchandise items and therefore do not appear separately. Since we have no other basis for measuring the incidence of these items, in compiling Table 8.9 it has simply been assumed that the provision of freight and insurance services by one region on its imports from the other is evenly distributed across the range of items which are traded. From thii point on the interesting questions concern the presentation and manipulation of the SAM data rather than its conceptual foundations. This final section can only touch on these issues since we have chosen to end this volume al: a point where the data base is poised for subsequent analytical use. We therefore restrict ourselves at this stage to alternative presentations of the data on aggregate flows which is given in Table 8.1, and leave final discutision of disaggregations within these details until our concluding chapter. Obvious tabulations to derive from the aggregate regional SAM shown as Table 8.1 are the respective aggregate SAMs for East and West Malaysia shown as Tables 7.3 and 2.1, respectively, They can be obtained in a relatively straightforward manner. To obt:ain the aggregate SAM for East Malaysia involves three steps: (i) Consolidate the current accounts for West Malaysia (accounts 1 to 5 and 9 to 11) with the Rest of the World current account (account 7*). (ii) Consolidate the capital account: for West Malaysia. (account 6) with that for the Rest of the World (account 8*). (iii) Set the diagonal entry in the East Malaysia commodity accounts equal to zero, and add the inil:ial entry as both a reccipt and an expenditure of the East Malaysia commodity account in its transactions with the consolidated account formed in step (i) above.
 - 240 - Strictly analogous steps, with the roles of East and West Malaysia reversed, yields the West Malaysia SAM shown as Table 2.1. The logic of the first two of these steps is evident from the definition of the Rest of the World, from East Malaysia's point of view, as the aggregation of West Malaysia and the Rest of the World as defined in Table 8.1. The third step follows from the discussion in the previous section of the present chapter. The essence of that discussion is that external transactions, which record exports f.o.b. and imports c.i.f., involve an element of double counting. Specifically, the insurance and freight service charges which a country earns in bringing goods from foreign markets to its own appears both as an export earning and as part of imports valued c.i.f.. This double counting is avoided, while account balances are retained, by treating these export earnings as an internal transfer within domestic commodity markats which is therefore excluded both from exports and, on a commodity by commodity basis, from import costs. If such a procedure is followed for all regions, then the aggregate SAM for any one region can be obtained by consolidation of the accounts for all other regions. A subsequent step is then needed to obtain import and export figures on the conventional basis: the double counting has to be reinstated by an adjustment of the tylpe specified in step 3 above. The simplest way of obtaining an aggregate SAM for All Malaysia from the data of Table 8.1 is to consolidate each of the various accounts for East Malaysia with the corresponding account for West Malaysia.  - 249 - CHAPTER 9 RESULTS AND REFLECTIONS 9.1 Consolidated Classification Scheme Throughout the previous chapters it has been apparent that the disaggregations and classifications for Wants, Factors, Households and Production have been about as detailed as the source data could sustain. It will be recalled that, for West Malaysia, the Household Income/Expenditure SurveyL' has provided the basis for the mapping of factors incomes to households; while the Labour Force Survey component of the same data set has provided the necessary basis for the mapping of value added from production activity accounts to factors. Further disaggregation of these survey results would have exacerbated our problems in having to deal with base data in which a number of cell entries are based on very few observations. In this respect, then, the classifications that have been adopted for Peninsular Malaysia represent a limit of meaningful disaggregation based on these sources. One consequence is that some of the estimates in earlier chapters are subject to rather wide margins of uncertainty, even though these margins are narrower than they would have been without the benefit of the inherent constraints that the SAM framework provides. These arguments suggest that for many purposes it may be preferable to work at a less disaggregated level than the one we have attempted. Also, some of our earlier analysis suggests that, in some instances, aspects of the classification criteria which we have previously adopted turn out to be of relatively little significance in defining groups which are significantly 1/ Malaysia, Department of Statistics (unpublished).
 - 250 - different. A case in point arises with respect to the race dimension of the factor accounts. The factor accounts for West Malaysia, discussed in Chapter 4, involve a classification of labor according to location (urban/rural), education level and race; as well as by industry of employment and household group. As was noted in Chapter 4, the results of estimating a wage matrix for these various labor types showed that the most significant influences on income stemmed from education level and industry of employment. Furthermore, the race dimension appears to have the least explanatory power in this context, in comparison not only with education but also relative to the locational dimension. It emerges, therefore, that apparent wage differences between ethnic groups can largely be explained by these other labor characteristics. Accordingly, the race dimension can be dropped as a labor classification criterion for many purposes. In contrast with the factor accounts, it is especially important to retain the race dimension as a classification criterion for households, and hence as an aspect of the distribution of income across institutions. This is because ethnic differences in living standards are a primary consideration in the context of planning and government policy in Malaysia. Thus the relevance of the SAM for policy purposes depends significantly on this feature, which our analysis has shown is contingent on the location and factor endowments of households of different ethnic groups. Given the above considerations and a general desire to produce a smaller, more manageable SAM for subsequent analytical purposes, Table 9.1 sets out a less detailed set of disaggregations and classifications than those
 - 251 - we have previously worked with. They have been derived with reference both to our sense of the accuracy of results previously obtained, and by suppressing details of classification which have turned out to be of little numerical significance. Beyond this, the detail in the activity and commodity accounts has been reduced in line with conventional criteria for sectoral definitions. Table 9.1 sets out the new classifications and shows their relationship to the old ones. The Wants accounts have been reduced from 33 to 20; the Commodity accounts from 59 to 26; and the Production Activities are now shown in 21 separate accounts rather than 30. As regards the Factor and Household accounts, these previously contained a considerable disaggregation for West Malaysia (51 and 33 accounts respectively). Suppressing the ethnic dimension in the labor classification for West Malaysia, together with some consolidation of the groups defined by education level, now reduces the disaggregation in the factor accounts as a whole to only 9 categories. Less drastically, the household accounts have been reduced to 20 categories. This has been achieved first by combining households whose heads are employers with those in which the head is an own account worker. Secondly, all employment status categories have been combined for those households whose members belong to the ethnic class 'others'. This reduced amount of detail still allows a good deal of scope in defining household groups and for identifying important distributional issues between major socio-economic categories.

 - 269 - 9.4 An All Malaysia SAM with Regional Components In Table 8.11 an aggregate SAM for All Malaysia has been set out whicly retains certain aspects of the regional distinction between East and West Malaysia. The disaggregated SAM presented in this section is similar in spirit. It contains separate household and factor accounts for East and West Malaysia, following the details for classification given in Table 9.1. Similarly, as in Table 8.11, there is no regional distinction in the accounts for Companies, Government, Activities and Indirect taxes, nor for the combined capital account for domestic institutions. Hence the only departure from the format of Table 8.11 is in the treatment of commodities. In Table 8.11, commodity transactions are shown separately for East and West Malaysia. Here these two sets of commodity accounts are to be combined so that, in Table 9.13 below, there are just 26 outlay accounts for commodities, corresponding to the classification definitions given in Table 9.1. In combining the separate regional commodity accounts in this way, it is necessary to suppress the freight and insurance earnings of each region in providing its own imports. The arguments for doing so have been discussed in Chapter 8. If such transactions were to be retained then double-counting of these elements would be involved in the computation of commodity supplies. This is because they are an element both of a region's imports and of its exports as discussed in Chapter 8. By suppressing these elements in the commodity accounts, the gross outputs for activities in All Malaysia are simply obtained as sums of gross outputs in each region. But commodity supplies are no longer simple sums because such a procedure would involve an element of double counting.
 - 270 - Corresponding to the consolidation of the separate regional accounts for commodities, the rest of the world is now defined as all territory outside Malaysia as a whole. Chapter 8 has shown how the corresponding import and export figures can be estimated. These results are now used in the present SAM at the 26-commodity level of detail as set out in Table 9.1. The results for our All Malaysia SAM are presented in Tables 9.11 to 9.15. Again the presentation is from the outlay perspective. Thus Table 9.11 gives the outlay accounts for wants for All Malaysia and is simply an aggregation of the similar tables for West and East Malaysia shown as Tables 9.2 and 9.7. Next, Table 9.12 brings together the detail on institutions current accounts from Tables 9.3 (West Malaysia) and 9.10 (East Malaysia). The All Malaysia commodity accounts are then given in Table 9.13. In Table 9.14 the activities accounts for West (Table 9.5) and East Malaysia (Table 9.9) are brought together. And finally, in Table 9.15, the All Malaysia outlay accounts for factors (showing East and West separately) are presented, together with the outlay accounts for the domestic institutions capital account, the indirect tax account and the external (rest of the world) accounts. This final table therefore combines results from Tables 9.6 and 9.10 which have set out the corresponding detail separately for each region. 9.5 Reflections on the Study The various SAMs set out in previous sections of this chapter and, more generally, throughout this book can be used for a variety of purposes. But they also do far more than this in showing how these different aspects of structure are interrelated, one with another, and with the household and factoral distributions of income. Thus the tables facilitate quantitative thought about how changes in one part of the structure will have consequences for another. Not least, one can trace through the tables the potential impact of some exogenous change, such as a change in government expenditure, on each of the different household groups within the economy, and hence on the level and distribution of income. From the perspective of a national accounts statistician, the main feature of the approach to SAMs in this volume may be the attempt to forge detailed and consistent links between value added and final demand via the income and outlay accounts for factors and institutions. Such consistency is an obvious goal in national income computations. However, the usual approach to it is via the commodity and activity accounts. Following this normal approach, value added, disaggregated by activities, can be estimated in a manner which is consistent with final demand disaggregated by commodities. And it is this latter approach which has been used in computing the National Accounts for Malaysia, which accordingly represent contemporary best practice procedures for such computations. However, our concern in this study (and in earlier onesI/) has been to go beyond these established procedures and to subject the national accounts estimates to a further set of restrictions. Thus the consistency which is a novel feature in our work is to require value added, disaggregated by factors, to be consistent with final demands, 1/ See, for example, Pyatt and Roe with Lindley, Round and others (1977), and Pyatt and Round (1977).
 - 277 - disaggregated by institutions, and for this second set of consistency requirements to be obtained via the detailed income and outlay accounts for factors and institutions. There can be no doubt that if national income was initially estimated subject to both sets of restrictions, then superior estimates of the national accounts would emerge. In this field additional consistency checks can invariably work towards improved estimates. However, in the present study we have not tried to re-estimate the national income, but rather have taken the national income estimates derived via the commodity/activity balance approach as datum. This is because we have not wanted to change figures which have previously been established. In consequence, the second type of consistency, i.e. that which is obtained via the factor and institutions accounts, has had to be achieved entirely by adjustment of the flows through these accounts. Hence, rather than use both types of consistency simultaneously, our method in this volume has been a sequential one. A consequence is that the potential gain in accuracy from use of the more general, simultaneous approach has been sacrificed. The extent of this sacrifice shows up in the difficulties of reconciliation which we have had to face, and in the various adjustment factors which it has been necessary to invoke. The extent to which these pragmatic procedures are thought to be unacceptable or to result in doubtful figures, is one measure of the sacrifice involved in treating the national accounts as previously estimated as sacrosanct. This way of expressing the role of factor and institution accounts in our procedures suggests that they represent a way of improving SAM estimation. This is correct. But it also misses an important aspect. The emphasis previously in national accounts compilation has encouraged increasing
 - 278 - detail in activity and commodity accounts, involving large input-output tables as a result. From a number of points of view this is a misplaced emphasis. To the extent that policy is concerned with the living standards of different groups in society, the disaggregation of institution and factor accounts is at a premium, and the case for disaggregated production accounts derived from their relevance in explaining the living standards of different groups. But it is the living standards of these groups which should be the starting point. It was a natural starting point for the pioneers of national accounting,-L/ and in our view it should be re-established as such if the object is to serve a development strategy which has the raising of living standards and equitable sharing in growth as its objectives. From this perspective, the main thrust of developments in national accounting for developing countries in recent years has been misguided. An approach to SAMs which emphasizes living standards via the income and outlay accounts for different institutions and factors has to be based on a high-quality survey of household income and expenditure patterns, and a similar survey for the corporate sector. We have therefore been particularly fortunate that such basic data is available for Malaysia, as well as a first- rate set of national accounts compiled according to SNA recommendations. In other countries it would be rare to have such material, and in those cases where household surveys do exist, we know of no case where major discrepancies 1/ The 17th century work of Gregory King is discussed in Pyatt and Thorbecke (1976).
 - 279 - between survey results and national accounts has not been revealed.-Y Nor is it obvious that such discrepancies should be read simply as a reflection of poor quality in survey results. It is quite reasonable to impute some of the discrepancy to bad national income estimation. From this point it follows that national income estimation could be improved by reference to household survey results. These arguments imply an orientation for household surveys in the income distribution field which has previously been lacking. Until now, such surveys have typically been designed to provide weights for a cost-of-living index and perhaps for other ad hoc purposes also. Only occasionally are they conceived as a way of monitoring living standards, and when they are, the initial design is innocent of any thoughts about using the survey results as a starting point for national income estimation. If survey results on the income and outlay accounts for factors and are to be used as an (initial) ingredient of national accounts compilation, then questions inevitably arise as to appropriate methods for reconciling inconsistent estimates of particular numbers within a SAM. This is simply because we can expect substantial discrepancies between survey results and previous methods of estimating national income. Much of this book has been taken up with discussion of the methods which we have used to resolve discrepancies. These methods are essentially informal, involving judgement and sub-routines (such as RAS) which have been invoked as and when we have 1/ The work of Altimir (1975) is particularly relevant in showing dlscrepancies for a number of Latin American countries between wage income generated in different activities as separately estimated by household surveys and national accounts.
 - 280 - felt them to be appropriate. In consequence the results depend significantly on the discretion we have exercised. Some element of this general approach is inevitable if final tables, uncluttered with numerous residual balancing errors, are to be avoided. However, opportunities are now becoming available for reduced reliance on subjective methods, thanks to recent developments in computer technology and algorithms.L/ It remains for the future to explore how these contributions might best be exploited. The reorientationiof national accounts which we have tried to illustrate in this volume provides a fresh starting point for discussion of systems of classification. In the first instance, the question is how to define the household groups whose living standards are to be quantified. In Chapter 3 we have discussed this issue, and argued in favor of socioeconomic categories as opposed to a grouping based on income levels. In addition to location and race, our preferred criterion is the occupational status of the household's main earner. It is no coincidence that this was Gregory King's preferred criterion, since it is perhaps self-evident that this is the natural way to disaggregate a society which is composed of family units. Starting from this perspective of the appropriate taxonomy for social stratification, the next step is to decide how factors should be classified. The ownership of factors underlies the primary source of income for households, which is from the provision of factor services. Hence the mapping we show from factors to institutions (matrix T3.2) is essentially determined 1/ Stone discusses a method in his foreward to Pyatt and Roe with Lindley, Round and others (1977). This has been developed subsequently by Byron (1978). An alternative, more recent contribution, is the work of Ranier von Saleski (1977), using a network approach as a special case of linear programming.
 - 281 - by the distribution of wealth in the form of ownership of the factors of production. This distribution therefore includes labor endowments, which are the crucial determinant of incomes for many. Debate on the role of education in the determination of wage differentials has been extensive and will no doubt continue. Meanwhile the statistical evidence (to which this study adds) continues to build up in favor of regarding education level as a primary criterion for the disaggregation of the labor force. Location also matters in our results, and one of our more interesting findings is that differences by race can be accounted for by these sets of considerations. A limitation of our work has been the failure to treat sex as an additional distinguishing characteristic of labor. The choice of taxonomies for households and labor go a long way to conditioning the type of model which can be built on the data base we have provided. In classifying households in terms of occupation, and labor by educational level, it is implicitly assumed that labor incomes depend more on the latter than the former. This is not something we have tested directly. However, our analysis in Chapter 4 has investigated the relationship between wage income and industry of employment. Unfortunately the results here are subject to statistical difficulties in reconciling survey results and national accounts aggregates when the latter are treated as datum. But even so, the methods adopted do provide an interesting alternative to estimating earnings functions by regression methods, and they do indicate that industry of emloyment is of some importance in determining earnings. Given these findings it is to be regretted that our study has simply adopted an industrial classification from the published national accounts. This is based purely on the grouping of establishments by commodity produced,
 - 282 - and therefore entirely ignores the level of technology being adopted. The model of production which underlies conventional national accounts assumes explicitly that there is a unique technology for producing each commodity. This assumption flies in the face of all the evidence on the importance of technological duality in developing countries. It is therefore a major limitation on the usefulness of our work that we have not been able to abandon the conventional classification scheme. Unless and until technical duality is captured as an essential dimension of production statistics, the relevance of national accounts to the issues we know to be fundamental will remain seriously circumscribed. In separating out the accounts for activities from those for commodities, the way is open for using criteria other than the commodities produced as a basis for disaggregating activities. Thus national income accounting need not be bound by the Leontief model. The opportunities which this presents have yet to be seized, and our knowledge of development is the worse for it. In basing our approach to labor incomes on a manpower matrix, an initial link is forged between the SAM and the broad range of demographic statistics. More broadly, our general philosophy puts considerable emphasis on the need to integrate social statistics with the major economic data system. In this area the main example is, of course, with respect to income distribution, and here we think we have made a significant start. But there are other possibilities which could and should be developed, starting with the link between the labor endowments of each household type and the manpower matrix description of employment by factor types and activities. Going beyond labor endowment statistics into the other aspects of wealth distribution is an obvious priority. Equally, data collection in this
 - 283 - area raises many problems which might be considered insuperable in particular cases. However, it should be noted that without a comprehensive set of data on assets, the chances for improved estimation of savings, investment and the flow of funds is strictly limited. Yet quite apart from the intrinsic interest of the distribution of wealth in its own right, flow of funds questions are being recognized increasingly as key elements in the determination of how the distribution of income evolves over time. Setting aside questions of wealth distribution, other areas exist in which an integration of social and economic statistics is called for. As the work of Meerman (1978) and (1980) illustrates, it is perfectly possible, and instructive, to treat public expenditures on certain services - health and education are prime examples - as income transfers from Government to the households of various types who receive these services. Such a treatment obviously enhances the view of income distribution which otherwise emerges, and it provides a crucial link between the current transactions of Government and the living standards of the people whom it is concerned to serve. Questions of living standards can be taken a step further in our framework by reference to the accounts for wants. As presented in this study, the accounts for wants are simply a set of commodity accounts in which it is convenient to express household expenditures. But there is no reason in principle why wants cannot be defined in terms of access to needs (adequate diet, clean water, sanitation, education, etc.) thus forging a major new link with social statistics. Clearly there are many conceptual issues to be resolved if this approach were to be pursued. But for now it may be useful simply to point out the possibility, or rather to express the view that an
 - 284 - integration of social and economic statistics in this area requires that the conceptual problems can be resolved. Most of the above points relate to issues which are not conventionally treated in national accounts and which we would like to bring into the forefront of discussion for the future. However, even in those areas which are conventionally treated, we have problems with the conventions. The previous discussion of activity classifications in relation to technology is a case in point. A further area in which we feel that current conventions are inappropriate is in the treatment of commodity transactions at basic, as opposed to market prices. Chapter 5 has discussed this issue at length. It ultimately reduces to a question of the model which underlies the accounting framework. In rejecting the fixed coefficients commodity technology model, we recognize that distribution plays an important part in determining the prices that households pay for goods, and that these prices can differ substantially by virtue of alternative distribution channels. At one extreme, market prices and producer prices are the same for subsistence households, but they can be very different for others. If these differences in prices are to be captured, then there is no alternative but to recognize different commodities according to different marketing arrangements. The treatment of commodity accounts at basic prices is simply an artificial construction which reduces the value of the data by facilitating a reduction in the detail of commodity accounts at the cost of masking important differences as between domestic and export sale prices or between consumption of own produce and the same goods as channeled through wholesale and retail outlets.
 - 285 - Our analysis of East Malaysia in Chapter 7 is at worst a rather tedious exercise which is necessary to move from the rich data sources for West Malaysia to an All Malaysia set of accounts. However, we would like to accord the analysis in Chapter 7 a somewhat higher status, as an example of how data for one economy might be borrowed, to calibrate a SAM for some other. Such a procedure may be alien to conventional statisticians. But in practice such procedures are being used in less systematic fashion in many countries and the issue should be to obtain the best possible estimates from whatever sources are available. Thus the invocation attributed to some statisticians: "no number can be more accurate than no number", runs diametrically across our perception of the right approach. Where the reader comes out on these issues will depend on their balance between the need for some quantitative basis for policy, and the nature of the responsibility which goes with being a purvevor of information to decision-makers. Putting together the SAMs for East and West Malaysia has raised conceptual issues of regional accounting which we try to resolve in Chapter 8. Numerically what is at stake here hardly justifies the depth of our discussion. But in the broader context of the general desire to have more of a regional nature included within the national accounts, it is important to get the conceptual issues straight; and this is what we hope to have done. In reaching the end of this study we are conscious that we have produced an elaborate and intricate text which relentlessly pursues consistency at the expense of broader discussion of the issues which are touched on in this final section and at various points in earlier chapters. It is left to the reader to decide whether our efforts support their avowed objective of seeking a reorientation of national accounts away from production
 - 286 - toward giving primacy to the question: who gets what? In this study we have tried to demonstrate that much can be done towards this end. But if the reader is not already apprised of the importance of this end, then, to pursue the point requires the further exercise of showing how the data can be used for policy purposes. Applications have not been discussed here and remain for subsequent publications. It has taken many years for national income accounts to reach their present level of sophistication. It may take many more before they are simplified and reoriented in the direction we favor.

Thus A has row totals Ai and column totals (in row vector form) i'A . Let x be the desired row totals, and let y' be the desired column totals. Then the problem is to form a new matrix B by modification of the matrix A such that (A.1) Bi = x and i'B = y The RAS method solves this problem by defining B as (A.2) r As B where r and s are diagonal matrices. The notation on the left-hand side of equation (A.2) is the source of the name 'RAS method'. It has been used extensively in estimation and updating of input-output tables following its rediscovery and initial application in this area by StoneX However, the method has a number of related antecedents. doc.repnme: Improving the macroeconomic data base : a SAM for Malaysia, 1970
doc.abstracts: The SAM for Malaysia addresses a number of conceptual issues and their practical solution which do not seem to have been treated elsewhere. This SAM is a large one, with a level of detail more nearly that at which national accounts are typically compiled, rather than the more aggregated formats which are often adopted as a basis for macro models or analysis. Malaysia's excellent set of national accounts make possible an initial exploration of the strengths and weaknesses of using market prices as the basis for evaluation of commodity balances, leading to some formal, algebraic treatment of the reasons for preferring this approach to other conventions. An extensive household survey, covering incomes, expenditures, and employment issues, complements the national accounts in defining the principle data sources. The major novelties of this SAM include: (i) it has been necessary to define a two-region SAM at the conceptual level; (ii) given the conceptual framework, the approach is essentially to estimate a SAM for East Malaysia and then to form the SAM for all Malaysia by combining this with a matched matrix for the West Malaysia states. These novelties should be of interest to others concerned with SAM estimation methods.
